item.title: Info tables omg omg omg
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz1 pplsuqbawlz_
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz1 wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:14, topic:300130”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=396414.msg2948643#msg2948643 date=1252355278]

[quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=396414.msg2948623#msg2948623 date=1252354435]

because everyone uses java’s naming conventions, right? nobody thinks they’re ugly and realises you can use whatever you please.
[/quote]except for the fact that this doesnt follow javas naming conventions. it follows c-style naming conventions, just like jagex

you totally missed the point.
he means that no one is forcing you to use java conventions, you can use whatever you want
ps how do you know what conventions jagex use? where have you seen their source code?
[/quote]the client and loader classes arent renamed. methods such as providesignlink() are not renamed either. and in the 194 revision the signlink class wasn’t obfuscated, as taharok mentioned

super_ shut the fuck up, i simply missed the sarcasm :([/quote]

Methods that are shared between two applications need to share names so that when run in the same application they reflect each other! ZKM isn’t so great about this functionality, it’s easier to leave it non-refactored.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:10, topic:300130”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=396414.msg2948218#msg2948218 date=1252340757]
because everyone uses java’s naming conventions, right? nobody thinks they’re ugly and realises you can use whatever you please.

You either are:

[ul][li]a) retarded[/li]
[li]b) blind[/li][/ul]

[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 07, 2009, 09:15:01 pm[/size][hr][quote=“la­wl, post:11, topic:300130”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=396414.msg2948623#msg2948623 date=1252354435]

item.title: Info tables omg omg omg
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:11, topic:300130”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=396414.msg2948623#msg2948623 date=1252354435]

because everyone uses java’s naming conventions, right? nobody thinks they’re ugly and realises you can use whatever you please.
[/quote]except for the fact that this doesnt follow javas naming conventions. it follows c-style naming conventions, just like jagex

you totally missed the point.
he means that no one is forcing you to use java conventions, you can use whatever you want
ps how do you know what conventions jagex use? where have you seen their source code?[/quote]

signlink.java from RS2 client release 194:

/* signlink - Decompiled by JODE
 * Visit http://jode.sourceforge.net/
 */
package sign;
import java.applet.Applet;
import java.io.DataInputStream;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileInputStream;
import java.io.FileOutputStream;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.net.InetAddress;
import java.net.Socket;
import java.net.URL;

public final class signlink implements Runnable
{
    static final int clientversion = 194;
    public static Applet mainapp;
    public static boolean sunjava;
    private static boolean active;
    private static InetAddress socketip;
    private static int socketreq;
    private static Socket socket = null;
    private static int threadreqpri = 1;
    private static Runnable threadreq = null;
    private static String dnsreq = null;
    private static String dns = null;
    private static String loadreq = null;
    private static byte[] loadbuf = null;
    private static String savereq = null;
    private static byte[] savebuf = null;
    private static String urlreq = null;
    private static DataInputStream urlstream = null;
    public static String midi = null;
    public static String jingle = null;
    public static int jinglelen = 3500;
    public static int looprate = 100;
    public static boolean reporterror = true;
    public static String errorname = "";
    
    public static final void startpriv(InetAddress inetaddress) {
	if (!active) {
	    socketip = inetaddress;
	    Thread thread = new Thread(new signlink());
	    thread.setDaemon(true);
	    thread.start();
	}
    }
    
    public final void run() {
	if (!active) {
	    active = true;
	    String string = findcachedir();
	    for (;;) {
		if (socketreq != 0) {
		    try {
			socket = new Socket(socketip, socketreq);
		    } catch (Exception exception) {
			socket = null;
		    }
		    socketreq = 0;
		}
		if (threadreq != null) {
		    Thread thread = new Thread(threadreq);
		    thread.setDaemon(true);
		    thread.start();
		    thread.setPriority(threadreqpri);
		    threadreq = null;
		}
		if (dnsreq != null) {
		    try {
			dns = InetAddress.getByName(dnsreq).getHostName();
		    } catch (Exception exception) {
			dns = "unknown";
		    }
		    dnsreq = null;
		}
		if (loadreq != null) {
		    loadbuf = null;
		    try {
			File file = new File(string + loadreq);
			if (file.exists()) {
			    int i = (int) file.length();
			    loadbuf = new byte[i];
			    DataInputStream datainputstream
				= (new DataInputStream
				   (new FileInputStream(string + loadreq)));
			    datainputstream.readFully(loadbuf, 0, i);
			    datainputstream.close();
			}
		    } catch (Exception exception) {
			/* empty */
		    }
		    loadreq = null;
		}
		if (savereq != null) {
		    try {
			FileOutputStream fileoutputstream
			    = new FileOutputStream(string + savereq);
			fileoutputstream.write(savebuf, 0, savebuf.length);
			fileoutputstream.close();
		    } catch (Exception exception) {
			/* empty */
		    }
		    savereq = null;
		}
		if (urlreq != null) {
		    try {
			urlstream
			    = new DataInputStream(new URL
						      (mainapp.getCodeBase(),
						       urlreq)
						      .openStream());
		    } catch (Exception exception) {
			urlstream = null;
		    }
		    urlreq = null;
		}
		try {
		    Thread.sleep((long) looprate);
		} catch (Exception exception) {
		    /* empty */
		}
	    }
	}
    }
    
    public static final String findcachedir() {
	String[] strings
	    = { "c:/windows/", "c:/winnt/", "d:/windows/", "d:/winnt/",
		"e:/windows/", "e:/winnt/", "f:/windows/", "f:/winnt/", "c:/",
		"~/", "/tmp/", "" };
	String string = ".file_store_32";
	for (int i = 0; i < strings.length; i++) {
	    try {
		String string_0 = strings[i];
		if (string_0.length() > 0) {
		    File file = new File(string_0);
		    if (!file.exists())
			continue;
		}
		File file = new File(string_0 + string);
		if (file.exists() || file.mkdir())
		    return string_0 + string + "/";
	    } catch (Exception exception) {
		/* empty */
	    }
	}
	return null;
    }
    
    public static final long gethash(String string) {
	string = string.trim();
	long l = 0L;
	for (int i = 0; i < string.length() && i < 12; i++) {
	    char c = string.charAt(i);
	    l *= 37L;
	    if (c >= 'A' && c <= 'Z')
		l += (long) ('\001' + c - 'A');
	    else if (c >= 'a' && c <= 'z')
		l += (long) ('\001' + c - 'a');
	    else if (c >= '0' && c <= '9')
		l += (long) ('\033' + c - '0');
	}
	return l;
    }
    
    public static final void looprate(int i) {
	looprate = i;
    }
    
    public static final byte[] cacheload(String string) {
	if (!active)
	    return null;
	if (loadreq != null)
	    return null;
	loadreq = String.valueOf(gethash(string));
	while (loadreq != null) {
	    try {
		Thread.sleep(1L);
	    } catch (Exception exception) {
		/* empty */
	    }
	}
	return loadbuf;
    }
    
    public static final void cachesave(String string, byte[] is) {
	if (active && savereq == null && is.length <= 2000000) {
	    savebuf = is;
	    savereq = String.valueOf(gethash(string));
	    while (savereq != null) {
		try {
		    Thread.sleep(1L);
		} catch (Exception exception) {
		    /* empty */
		}
	    }
	}
    }
    
    public static final Socket opensocket(int i) throws IOException {
	socketreq = i;
	while (socketreq != 0) {
	    try {
		Thread.sleep(50L);
	    } catch (Exception exception) {
		/* empty */
	    }
	}
	if (socket == null)
	    throw new IOException("could not open socket");
	return socket;
    }
    
    public static final String dnslookup(String string) {
	return "unknown";
    }
    
    public static final void startthread(Runnable runnable, int i) {
	threadreqpri = i;
	threadreq = runnable;
    }
    
    public static final DataInputStream openurl(String string)
	throws IOException {
	urlreq = string;
	while (urlreq != null) {
	    try {
		Thread.sleep(50L);
	    } catch (Exception exception) {
		/* empty */
	    }
	}
	if (urlstream == null)
	    throw new IOException("could not open: " + string);
	return urlstream;
    }
    
    public static final void reporterror(String string) {
	if (reporterror) {
	    System.out.println("Error: " + string);
	    try {
		string = string.replace('@', '_');
		string = string.replace('&', '_');
		string = string.replace('#', '_');
		DataInputStream datainputstream
		    = openurl("reporterror" + 194 + ".cgi?error=" + errorname
			      + " " + string);
		datainputstream.readLine();
		datainputstream.close();
	    } catch (IOException ioexception) {
		/* empty */
	    }
	}
    }
}

I heard their stream class was also unobfuscated in the early releases of their login applet, but I doubt anyone has any copies anymore.

Read full topic

@Graham wrote:

oksuper_:

Wow it appears a lot of you are idiots and think this is a source-code leak. It’s not, it just shows how the info tables work.

Why did you use Jagex’s conventions then? Kind of suggests you wanted to make people believe it was a leak.

@Jython wrote:

God bless the LocalVariableTable attribute.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 06, 2009, 07:30:26 pm[/size][hr]Wow it appears a lot of you are idiots and think this is a source-code leak. It’s not, it just shows how the info tables work.

item.title: Info tables omg omg omg
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“Graham, post:5, topic:300130”][quote author=peterbjornx link=topic=396414.msg2946084#msg2946084 date=1252222492]
did you refactor it or was it another leak?
[/quote]

He refactored it as the local variables have proper names (instead of i1, i2, etc). Local variable names aren’t preserved when java is compiled to bytecode.[/quote]yes they are, they arent a required attribute so they are usually the first thing an obfuscator strips

Read full topic

item.description:
@Graham wrote:

peterbjornx:

did you refactor it or was it another leak?

He refactored it as the local variables have proper names (instead of i1, i2, etc). Local variable names aren’t preserved when java is compiled to bytecode.

item.title: Info tables omg omg omg
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

It’s not exactly the file system class… to find that class lookup seekablefile.seek() invoke and see if one arg is pushed like:

iload X sipush 512 imul
Or whatever. This is basically doing:

cursectorid * 512

This class is the indexed filesystem class. The class I pasted is the interface they use over it that makes it much easier to use. It lets you lookup entries by name, and have sub-entry abstraction, among other goodies like checksums and ‘versions’ (I’m not too sure on this field of the information table format [entry X inside the indexed file system 255 where X is the indexed file system # and X != 255. If X == 255, the file is the overall checksum file hard-coded in modern new-engine servers as ‘update keys’ or ‘uKeys’])

Read full topic
